q:

q:
*** 5 points question ***

q:
*** 5 points question ***

What is correct?
In a residential area ...

A. ... is the maximum speed limit 25 km/hour.
B. ... are cars allowed to park on the left and right of the direction of travel.
C. ... may pedestrians and cyclists use the full lane.
e:
[Violations of the 3th and 4th degree on our page Theory B: nr. 32]
LESSON 6 – ‘Special places’.
The maximum speed limit is 20 km/hour.
Only pedestrians may use the full road.

q:
*** 5 points question ***

A school bus has stopped and the hazard warning lights are being used. What do you have to do?

A. Stop.
B. Slow down and stop if necessary.
C. Drive on.
e:
[Violations of the 3th and 4th degree on our page Theory B: nr. 32]
LESSON 11 – ‘The lights’.
If a school bus stops so that students can go out, the driver has to switch on the four direction indicators or hazard warning lights.
Upcoming vehicles are obliged to reduce speed and if it is necessary to stop
They should be careful while driving by the bus.

q:
*** 5 points question ***

In this street, two cars want to cross each other.
How much lateral distance must be kept?

A. Sufficient.
B. 1,5 meters.
C. 1 meter.
e:
[Violations of the 3th and 4th degree on our page Theory B: nr. 32]
LESSON 14 – ‘Crossing’.
The traffic regulations don’t define 'how much' it must be. There is written: 'sufficient'.

q:
*** 5 points question ***

The blue car driver approaches the back of the agent.

A. He must stop.
B. He may turn to the right.
e:
[Violations of the 3th and 4th degree on our page Theory B: nr. 32]
LESSON 17 – ‘Qualified persons’.
If an officer has one or two arms stretched out horizontally, this is a stop signal for all traffic approaching from in front of or from behind the outstretched arms.

q:
*** 5 points question ***

What is the hierarchical order?

A. 1 - 2 - 3.
B. 3 - 2 - 1.
C. 3 - 1 - 2.
e:
[Violations of the 3th and 4th degree on our page Theory B: nr. 32]
LESSON 17 – ‘Qualified persons’.
At the top of the commands of an agent.
Then the traffic lights.
Than the road signs.
Then the traffic rules.

q:
*** 5 points question ***

A crossroad without traffic signs.
In what situation the pedestrian has priority?

A. Only drawing A.
B. Only drawing B.
C. Drawing A + B.
e:
[Violations of the 3th and 4th degree on our page Theory B: nr. 32]
LESSON 21 – ‘Priority and changing directions’.
A car that changes direction, should give priority to pedestrians who cross the road where the car wants to go.

q:
*** 5 points question ***

An intersection with traffic signs.
In what situation the pedestrian has priority?

A. Only drawing A.
B. Only drawing B.
C. Drawing A + B.
e:
[Violations of the 3th and 4th degree on our page Theory B: nr. 32]
LESSON 21 – ‘Priority and changing directions’.
A car that changes direction, should give priority to pedestrians who cross the road where the car wants to go.

[Violations of the 3th and 4th degree on our page Theory B: nr. 32]
LESSON 7 – ‘The pedestrians’.

q:
*** 5 points question ***

The barriers are still fully open, but the alarm signal is clearly audible.
Can you still drive on the road?
e:
[Violations of the 3th and 4th degree on our page Theory B: nr. 32]
LESSON 18 – ‘Traffic lights’.
No. That would be a serious offense !!!

q:
*** 5 points question ***

The traffic light turns orange.
Can you still cross the intersection?

A. Yes.
B. Yes, if you endanger others by stopping.
C. No.
e:
[Violations of the 3th and 4th degree on our page Theory B: nr. 32]
LESSON 18 – ‘Traffic lights’.
Orange says you have to stop. Except if you are too close to the intersection, and you put the driver behind you at risk.

q:
*** 5 points question ***

e:
[Violations of the 3th and 4th degree on our page Theory B: nr. 32]
LESSON 16
The red sign says that drivers are forbidden to overtake a vehicle with more than two wheels on the left.

e:
[Violations of the 3th and 4th degree on our page Theory B: nr. 32]
LESSON 16
The red sign says that drivers are forbidden to overtake a vehicle with more than two wheels on the left.
